page.title: 04Ecology of Longdon (Flora)
page.content: "Longdon" is derived from the Anglo- Saxon meaning "large dune" or long curving ridge. The{Severn-Trent Water Board }test- drilled Longdon Marsh with a view to making a reservoir to serve North Worcestershire. Although the subsoil was impervious clay, the cost was prohibitive. The marsh has traces of salt in it and{fennel}grows freely there. {Wild orchids}have been found in 2B. The indigenous trees are {elm}and {willow }though the elm is struggling after the ravages of Dutch elm disease in the l97O's. The local school children in twenty years have planted over 200 trees of different species. In a strip of wood by the main road there are an unusually high number of {yew}trees.
